description: From Middle English blee, ble, from Old English blēo, bleoh (“color, hue; complexion, form”), from Proto-West Germanic *blīu (“color, blee”).

Cognate with Scots ble, blee, blie (“color, complexion”), Old Frisian blī, blie (“color, hue; complexion”) (whence North Frisian bläy, Saterland Frisian Bläier), Middle Dutch blie, blye (“color”). Doublet of bly.

entries.meaning: (rare, chiefly poetic) Color, hue. [from 9th to early 17th c.]
examples: IT was a Mothering Sunday ; / The sky was clear to see / Above the white, white snowdrop, / And the crocus of golden blee.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Color of the face, complexion, coloring. [from 9th to early 17th c.]
examples: The sew she would not Latin heare, / But rudely rushed at the Frear, / That he blinked all his blee ; / And when she would have taken her hold, / The Fryar leaped as Jesus wold, / And bealed him with a tree.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Consistency, form, texture. [from 9th to early 17th c.]
(East Anglia) General resemblance, likeness; appearance, aspect, look.
examples: Meane beautie doth soone fade: therof playn hee, / Who nothing loves in woman, but her blee.

description: Associated with Smash Hits magazine, where it may have originated.
